content: scalloped baby blanket by lesley karpiuk the pink toque / geeksoap net https //www ravelry com/designers/lesley-karpiuk materials us h/8-5 00mm crochet hook 3 skeins 1365 yards/15 oz bernat softee baby solids in pale blue notes this blanket is built body first then the scalloped top and bottom edges are done afterwards the body has a simple pattern that even the newest crocheter can handle stitches single_crochet = single_crochet double_crochet = double_crochet chain = chain st = stitch shell described below blanket body chain 110 row 1 single_crochet in second chain from hook single_crochet in each st across 109 sts row 2 - 20 chain 1 single_crochet in each st across 109 the decorative pattern row 21 chain 2 double_crochet in each st across 109 row 22 chain 1 single_crochet in each st across 109 row 23 chain 2 double_crochet in each st across 109 you will alternate between doing 20 row of single_crochet and then the three row that make up the decorative pattern until the blanket is as long as you want it to be basic pattern *20 row of single_crochet ch2 1 row of double_crochet ch1 1 row of single_crochet ch2 1 row of double_crochet* repeat from * to * until you reach your desired length i went around 34″ or so since you start with 20 row of single_crochet make sure ​ ​ you end with a completion of a group of 20 row of single_crochet to make it look even so don t end with the double_crochet/single_crochet/double_crochet pattern border once the body of the blanket is the length you want you re going to immediately turn your work and do the shell back across that final row shell *skip 2 chain double_crochet 5 times in the third chain skip 2 chain single_crochet in the third chain* across 18 shells once you have completed your last shell you ll now turn your work clockwise and slip_stitch down the long side of the blanket to get to the opposite end once you get there turn your work again clockwise and you ll see you re at the opposite long end of the blanket your first set of shell stitches should be on the furthest end from you now shell across this bottom row you now have shell scallops at the two farthest ends of the blanket turn your work clockwise one final time and slip_stitch up the long side until you reach your initial shell you should have made a complete square trip around the outer edge of your blanket giving the two furthest ends from each other a pretty scalloped edge and slip stitching the two longest sides fasten_off and weave in all ends tada this pattern and photos copyright ©2009 by lesley karpiuk /
